article.headline: Cincinnati 82, DePaul 60
article.story: CINCINNATI (AP) -- Forwards Eric Hicks and Cedric McGowan dominated up front Wednesday night, leading Cincinnati to an 82-60 victory over DePaul in the schools' Big East basketball debut. Cincinnati (12-2) has won nine in a row with solid defense and a balanced lineup. The Bearcats showed their new conference that they've got a little bit of everything. Jihad Muhammad scored 20 points in a fastbreak attack that featured four players in double digits. Hicks had 20 points and 14 rebounds, and McGowan added 13 points and 20 rebounds, helping Cincinnati dominate the boards 53-35. DePaul (7-5) hasn't won in Cincinnati since Feb. 20, 1992, dropping its last 15 games on the Bearcats' court. The schools have played at least twice a year over the past 14 years, first in the Great Midwest and then in Conference USA. The Bearcats have gotten the better of their matchups no matter what the conference, winning 27 of their last 31 games. Sammy Mejia led DePaul with 20 points. The Blue Demons shot only 35.9 from the field, going 5-of-17 from behind the 3-point arc. Only 8,605 fans showed up for Cincinnati's inaugural game in the Big East, showing that the program has a long way to go in recovering from coach Bob Huggins' unpopular ouster last August by school president Nancy Zimpher. The Bearcats haven't come close to a sellout in their 13,176-seat arena. Big East commissioner Mike Tranghese posed for a photo with the two head coaches at midcourt before the game, and new Cincinnati athletic director Mike Thomas and his family were applauded on court during an early timeout. Zimpher did not appear. That left the attention on a game that was close until Cincinnati's man-to-man defense put on the squeeze midway through the first half. Mejia, the Blue Demons' leading scorer and best player in the last seven games, hit three open shots as they pulled out to a 12-7 lead. That's when the Bearcats latched on and shut down the Blue Demons, holding them to 2-of-17 shooting the rest of the half. DePaul got so rattled that two of its passes wound up in the arms of Cincinnati coaches and players on the bench. Hicks had 12 points in the first half, two of them dunks off rebounds, as Cincinnati pulled ahead 35-23 -- DePaul's biggest halftime deficit of the season. McGowan had nine rebounds in the half. Cincinnati opened the second half with a 10-3 spurt that left the Blue Demons dispirited. Hicks scored and was fouled, then missed the free throw but beat slow-to-react defenders to the ball and scored again for a 45-26 lead that was never threatened.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).
